posts.title: Logic Pro X ‚Äì Notes Chase Settings
posts.text: Tired of not hearing some MIDI notes when hitting the play button? üîáSee these MIDI notes in your piano roll? Even if they seem to be a single block, they‚Äôre indeed composed of two separate MIDI events: Note ON and Note OFF. If your playhead is positionned somewhere after the start of a note block, hitting play won‚Äôt send any MIDI Note ON event. Result: Logic Pro X doesn‚Äôt know it should play something, and your note remains desperately silent üò•. Thankfully, there‚Äôs a simple way to prevent this behavior, called Notes Chase. Let‚Äôs unveil the few steps how to enable this pro settings. Learn this quick tip

posts.title: Logic Pro X ‚Äì Enable Advanced Tools
posts.text: If there‚Äôs a single tip to know‚Ä¶ üßêIt‚Äôs definitively this one. By default, Logic Pro X is more looking like the big brother of Garage Band than a tool built for pros! But its real power can be unleashed if you look into the app‚Äôs Advanced Settings. In this quick tutorial, you‚Äôll learn how to unlock Logic Pro X‚Äôs full potential. üî• Learn this quick tip
